Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Transient Absorption Spectrometer for Multidisciplinary Research in Chemistry, Materials Science and Solar Energy Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Elizabeth Young from Amherst College and colleagues Alexi Arango (Mount Holyoke), Michael Barnes (University of Massachussetts-Amherst) and Sankaran Thayumanavan (University of Massachussetts-Amherst) will acquire a transient absorption spectrometer with a femtosecond Ti:sapphire amplifier system for a five-college consortium (Amherst College, Mount Holyoke College, Smith College, Hampshire Colleges and University of Massachusetts-Amherst). In general, tunable Ti:sapphire lasers that emit red and near-infrared light are used to irradiate a substance to investigate how they respond to short energy pulses. This provides information on the molecular structure and interactions between atoms. The ultrafast (femtosecond) methods allow study of important biological mechanisms such as the charge transfer dynamics in photosynthesis reaction centers that have important implications in how plants utilize solar energy to produce food.

This award will enhance research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) investigation of charge separation (CS) and recombination (CR) dynamics in organic photovoltaic materials; (b) studys of covalently-linked donor-acceptor (D-A) molecules based on BODIPY photooxidant and CS and CR in thin-film bilayer photovoltaic assemblies; and (c) studies of exciton dynamics in crystalline and semicrystalline polymer aggregates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ultrafast time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy is critical to the study of fundamental processes that impact our daily lives. By using lasers with ultrafast capabilities to study excited-state properties of molecules and materials, specifically rapid charge transfer (CT), insight is gained to the nature of many fundamental processes that are critical to development of technology. This grant funded the establishment of a transient absorption (TA) laser facility at Amherst College for use by the Five College community and beyond. TA is the most well-established technique for characterization of excited-state properties and verification of charge transfer processes and proved critically important to scientists in the area. This facility created a tremendous opportunity that enhanced the research efforts and productivity within the Five College Community and their collaborators throughout the country and abroad.

 

Research of critical important to society and technology was performed in the facility and included the study of (1) new molecular,  polymeric and, nanostructured systems integral to creating solar cells and lighting that are more efficient, more cost effective and more easily manufactured on a large scale than current technology, (2) molecular properties of new drugs designed for photodynamic therapy that will enhance the quality and efficacy of treatment for cancer tumors, (3) polymers containing internal charge transfer states that can be used in a host of sensing applications both in solution and in solid state devices, (4) metal-catalyzed hydrophosphination to selectively add P–H bond across unsaturated bonds, (5) multiple-bonded complexes that can serve as model systems to understand multi-proton and multi-electron reactivity towards small molecule activation in critical energy conversion reactions.

 

The work carried out at the facility enabled graduate students and undergraduate research students to participate in fundamental and cutting-edge spectroscopy with applicability to chemistry, material science, polymers, and physics. The ultrafast laser instrumentation was housed in a shared-use laboratory at Amherst College, a primarily undergraduate institution. Undergraduate students who carried out the research activities in these projects performed multi-disciplinary and highly collaborative work with the help of graduate students from UMass-Amherst that allowed them to develop a deep understanding of spectroscopy and to apply that expertise to a wide range of scientific challenges. The experiences and training the students received by carrying out independent, self-directed research, and the exposure to sophisticated scientific equipment such as the transient absorption system enabled by this project, have prepared these members of society to become deep and careful thinkers who can effectively advocate to the broader public about the benefits of science and exploratory research valued by the NSF.
